abstract: Barnes & Noble’s poison-pill plan was reasonable attempt to defend the book seller against a potentially shareholder-unfriendly takeover attempt, a Delaware judge ruled on Thursday.
snippet: Barnes & Noble’s poison-pill plan was reasonable attempt to defend the book seller against a potentially shareholder-unfriendly takeover attempt, a Delaware judge ruled on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: 7:07 p.m. | Updated  Ronald W. Burkle is pursuing a proxy fight with Barnes & Noble. He filed late Thursday to replace three board members with his candidates, including himself, at the annual meeting late next month and he proposed amending the company’s poison pill.

headline.main: Strine Sides With Barnes & Noble in Burkle Fight

byline.original: By Michael J. de la Merced
